dcterms:title: Increased frequency of clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential in Bloom syndrome probands and carriers
dcterms:abstract: Bloom syndrome (BSyn, OMIM #210900) is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by growth restriction, sun sensitivity, insulin resistance, mild immune deficiency, and increased risk of early-onset malignancy. BSyn cases are caused by homozygous or compound heterozygous pathogenic variants (PV) in BLM, with over 547 different PV identified in ClinVar. The Bloom Syndrome Registry (BSR) recently reported that 53% of participants had developed cancer, with hematologic malignancies being the most common cancer risk. While several studies have shown no association of carriers having increased risk, recent studies have identified increased risk of cancers in BLM PV carriers such as colorectal cancer, breast cancer and mesothelioma.

dcterms:hasPart: A research paper published in Haematologica in January 2025 titled Increased frequency of clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential in Bloom syndrome probands and carriers investigates Bloom syndrome which is characterized by growth restriction sun sensitivity insulin resistance mild immune deficiency and increased cancer risk Bloom syndrome is caused by pathogenic variants in BLM gene with over 547 different variants identified in ClinVar The Bloom Syndrome Registry reported 53 percent of participants developed cancer primarily hematologic malignancies while recent studies have shown increased risk of colorectal cancer breast cancer and mesothelioma in BLM variant carriers The study analyzed exome sequencing data from 29 peripheral blood DNA samples from the Bloom Syndrome Registry including 10 BSyn probands and their biological parents using Illumina NovaSeq S1 flowcell Nextera DNA Flex Pre-Enrichment Library Prep and Roche NimbleGen exome capture kit The research explored clonal hematopoiesis which involves somatic mutations in leukemia-related genes occurring in hematopoietic cells The study found that germline variants in DNA repair genes and telomere maintenance genes are associated with increased prevalence of clonal hematopoiesis Hematopoietic stem cells demonstrated capability for clonal expansion and proliferation CHIP is associated with an annual increased risk of leukemia ranging from 0.5 to 1.0 percent with some Bloom syndrome patients developing acute lymphoblastic leukemia and acute myeloid leukemia DNA variants were analyzed with variant allele frequencies used to distinguish between somatic variants and germline variants revealing increased frequency of somatic variants in CHIP genes in both Bloom syndrome probands and carriers The research utilized GATK best-practices pipeline for quality control mapping and variant-calling with study participants providing informed consent under a Weill Cornell Medical College Institutional Review Board approved protocol
